title: Practical Utopias and Utopian Practices
abstractText:
The organisers seek to engage practitioners and academics in a series of meetings. The methodology will be one of participant discussion and short presentations, and each seminar will be guided by a series of questions.

Practitioners may be members of community projects (such as community-building initiatives and community-planning initiatives), health and caring professions, education, therapeutic communities, alternative or intentional communities, or non-governmental organisations. Further examples of practitioners are architects, town planners, creative artists, performers, people who live in intentional communities, members of pressure groups, health professionals, and activists. Academics might include specialists in law, planning, architecture, literary studies, medicine and health, politics, philosophy, ethics, education, cultural studies, art, sociology, social policy, religious studies and theology.

The series’ aims are:

  • To bring together a core group of utopian scholars with academics in related fields and participants in alternative or ‘utopian’ social practices
  • To contribute to the enrichment of utopian studies
  • To strengthen interdisciplinary networks, especially for research students and junior scholars
  • To explore the usefulness of the concepts and methods of utopian studies in understanding a range of alternative and experimental social practices
  • To develop resources for improvised social practices
